title: Right External Ear Canal Mass with Mixed Hearing Loss
chief_complaint: I have a mass growing in my right ear canal that causes pain and intermittent bloody discharge. I've had trouble hearing on that side for over a year, but I couldn't come in earlier because I didn't have insurance.

problem_summary.course: Hearing decreased in the right ear over the last year; symptoms persisted due to inability to seek care.
problem_summary.laterality: Right ear (symptoms), Left ear (reported good hearing).
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Mass in ear canal, intermittent bloody discharge, pain.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Extreme difficulty hearing in the right ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking evaluation now that care is accessible.

history.present_illness: Patient reports a mass growing in the right ear canal with intermittent bloody discharge and pain for over a year. Hearing has decreased in the right ear during this time.
history.medical_psych_history: Lack of insurance delayed medical intervention.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows severe mixed hearing loss (250-8000 Hz) with a profound mixed notch at 500 and 1000 Hz. Left ear shows mild rising to slight sensorineural loss (250-4000 Hz) sloping to moderate sensorineural loss (6000-8000 Hz).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores agree with PTA. Word recognition scores (WRS) are excellent bilaterally when presented at suprathreshold levels.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear revealed a flat tympanogram with small ear canal volume (consistent with mass occupying space). Left ear was normal.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes absent. Left ipsilateral reflexes normal; Left contralateral reflexes absent.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a severe-to-profound mixed hearing loss in the right ear, characterized by a significant air-bone gap and a flat tympanogram with reduced canal volume, consistent with the reported external ear mass. The left ear exhibits a mild-to-moderate sensorineural hearing loss. Speech recognition remains excellent in the right ear when sufficient volume is provided to overcome the conductive component.
counseling_points: The hearing loss in your right ear is 'mixed,' meaning there is both a permanent sensorineural component and a conductive component caused by the blockage in your ear canal.
The mass in your ear canal is blocking sound and likely causing the flat pressure test results.
You require an immediate referral to an ENT specialist to evaluate the mass and schedule surgical removal.
We will need to re-evaluate your hearing after the surgery to see how much hearing has been restored once the canal is clear.
notes_for_actor: Portray significant discomfort or pain in the right ear.
Emphasize the financial hardship (lack of insurance) as the primary reason for delaying treatment despite the bleeding and pain.
You believe your hearing is fine on the left side, though testing shows some mild loss there.
